prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Resolved CO(2-1) emission in the lensed (background) galaxy
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Resolve the CO(2-1) emission from the Einstein ring at 0.1arcsec resolution, the same resolution requested for CO(4-3) and CO(6-5) line ratio analysis.
Test the detectability of the tidal feature appearing in the HST-F110W filter (Figure 1 in Messias et al. 2014), and C17O(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target source has been observed by ALMA in Cycle-0. Its morphology consists of three knots, with the faintest appearing in the Nort-West. Its measured fluxes are the reference to estimate the requested sensitivity. We consider the knots to be point-like down to a resolution of 0.1arcsec as evidenced by HST and Keck observations, thus we do not correct for the finer resolution requested in this proposal. We consider AOT default weather conditions.
The CO(2-1) transition fluxes had to be measured in the clean component map, as a result of the poor resolution yielding a quasi unresolved emission (Figure 2). The faintest knot shows a line peak of ~3.5mJy and a line FWHM~460km/s. In order to balance proposal time and knot detectability, we request a sensitivity of 0.7mJy (5sigma detection) with a spectral resolution of 20km/s (which covers well the line FWHM).

The TDM velocity resolution (~80km/s) is too coarse to provide a proper sampling of the CO(2-1) line FWHM (460km/s). As a result, the coarsest of the FDM set-ups is chosen with a 16 spectral-averaging, reducing the data rate and providing a line-sampling factor of ~20, enough to address the proposed goal.
The representative window, tracing CO(2-1) is not centered at the transition sky-frequency (difference of 0.434GHz or ~1150km/s) in order to allow for the coveraged of C17O(2-1) with another spectral window. The frequency shift is such that it does not compromise the full coverage of CO(2-1) line (spanning <1000km/s).
The remainder two spectral windows probe the continuum, but nevertheless cover a frequency where SO2 lines are expected to be found.

The requested angular resolution was chosen so that beam matched observations in CO J:2-1, CO J:4-3, and CO J:6-5 could be pursued, provided the ALMA Cycle3 configurations. Also, the requested resolution is similar to that achieved by HST and Keck-AO observations (Messias et al. 2014).
The specified largest angular scale (LAS) is likely and upper limit, since the emission is limited to the Einstein ring (1.4arcsec in diameter, smaller than the recoverable LAS) and the tidal feature.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(2-1) isotopes: calibrate gas masses in lensed system and total mass of foreground galaxy (CO(1-0))
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Target CO(2-1) isotopes in the lensed (background) galaxy, expected to be detected at least in the brightest of the three knots, appearing in the South.
Additional molecular species from the lensed (background) galaxy which fall in the proposed spectral setup are: SiO(5-4), CS(4-3) and C34S(4-3).
Observe foreground galaxy CO(1-0) at 94.64GHz to constrain foreground dynamics within Einstein radius, thus improving the lens model.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target source has been observed by ALMA in Cycle-0. Its morphology consists of three knots, with the faintest appearing in the Nort-West. While its measured fluxes are the reference for the other science goals, here we adopt as reference the brightest of the knots, appearing in the South, due to the faintness of the targeted transitions. We consider the knot to be point-like down to a resolution of 0.1arcsec as evidenced by HST and Keck observations, thus we do not correct for the finer resolution requested in this proposal. We consider AOT default weather conditions.
From the ZSpec spectrum (Figure 2) we identify a ~2sigma detection (8.8+-4.2 Jy.km/s) of a channel corresponding to isotopes of background C18O(5-4) and foreground 13CO(3-2) and C18O(3-2). 13CO(5-4) seems to fall where the spectrum is faulty. Comparing to the channel where together background CO(5-4) and foreground CO(3-2) fall, we can estimate background isotopes abundance.
First, we assume the ZSpec channel tracing together foreground 12CO(3-2) and background 12CO(5-4), is mostly dominated by background emission assuming conservatively that the 12CO(4-3) intensity is equal to that of 12CO(5-4) intensity (usually, 12CO(5-4) is generally more intense in SMGs, Carilli & Walter 2013).
This also implies that the "isotopes-channel" has to be dominated by background C18O(5-4) emission. This is, if we assume foreground 12CO to 13CO and C18O intensity ratios of, respectively, 10 and 30, typical values observed in central regions of normal and IR-bright galaxies (e.g., Paglione et al. 2001, Tan et al. 2011), the foreground isotope fluxes are negligible compared to the total flux of the channel. Hence, 12CO to C18O J:5-4 intensity ratio is expected to be smaller than 4.5+-2.3, ie, 6.8 in the worst case.
Applying a 6.8 correction to the knot 12CO(2-1) line peaks, we request a sensitivity of 0.23mJy at a spectral resolution of 86 km/s, yielding, in a worst case scenario, a ~10sigma detection in the south knot (line peak at ~2.3mJy), a ~5.6sigma detection in the Nort-East knot (~1.3mJy), and a ~2.2sigma detection in the Nort-West knot (~0.5mJy).
We believe the 2sigma detection of this isotope ZSpec channel is real, for the following reason: CI 3P1-3P0 and CS(10-9) lines are detected in two channels of the ZSpec spectrum (at ~242GHz, Figure 2) also at the 2sigma level with a combined flux of 14.1+-5.5 Jy.km/s. Value which is very much in agreement with that observed by ALMA in Cycle-0 (14.2+-2.0 Jy.km/s).
The spectral resolution of 86km/s still allows to resolve the two CO(5-4) isotope lines, which are at a velocity separation of ~1140km/s.

Since the goal of this science goal is to maximise the isotope detecttion, TDM set-ups are chosen.
The exceptions are the spectral windows tracing CS(4-3) and foreground CO(1-0): - since CS(10-9) has been detected in the Cycle0 data-set, CS(4-3) is also expected to be detected within the implied integration time. Hence, the coarsest of the FDM set-ups is chosen with a 16 spectral-averaging, reducing the data rate and providing an expected line-sampling factor of ~14; - assuming a 200km/s line FWHM for the foreground CO(1-0) emission, and since we wish to dynamically resolve the line, the set-up is chosen (coarsest FDM, spectral averaging of 8, ~12km/s) to provide about 20 line elements. At this spectral resolution, the time on target set by the time estimator implies a rms of ~0.6mJy. We do not have a flux estimate for the foreground CO(1-0) emission, but rather a poor one for CO(2-1) of 33+-12 Jy.km/s (Messias et al.2014). adding the uncertainty on the foreground line FWHM and 2-1 to 1-0 line ratios, we restrain ourselves from assessing the detectability likelyhood, but instead mention that the chosen set-up gives us flexibility to maximise detection and achieve the goal.

The requested angular resolution was chosen to match the CO J:2-1 observations. Also, it provides about 14 elements to study the foreground CO(1-0) dynamics within the Einstein radius.
The specified largest angular scale (LAS) is an upper limit, since the isotope emission will likely be limited to the knots, and the foreground emission will be spread through the edge-on disc .

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(4-3) in lensed (background) galaxy: constrain lens model
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
All lines target the lensed (background galaxy):
Resolve the CO(4-3) emission from the Einstein ring at 0.1arcsec resolution, the same resolution requested for CO(2-1) and CO(6-5) line ratio analysis.
Trace the forbidden atomic Carbon 3P1-3P0 and the CS(10-9) transitions (already detected in the Cycle0 data-set).
Test the detectability of the tidal feature appearing in the HST-F110W filter (Figure 1 in Messias et al. 2014).
Test the detection of foreground continuum emission to improve foreground/background spectral energy distribution modelling.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target source has been observed by ALMA in Cycle-0. Its morphology consists of three knots, with the faintest appearing in the Nort-West. Its measured fluxes are the reference to estimate the requested sensitivity. We consider the knots to be point-like down to a resolution of 0.1arcsec as evidenced by HST and Keck observations, thus we do not correct for the finer resolution requested in this proposal. We consider AOT default weather conditions.
The Cycle-0 observation of CO(4-3) yields a line-peak flux of 15.5mJy in the faintest knot (at North-West). We take advantage of the line brightness to request a sensitivity of 0.77mJy with a 20km/s spectral resolution (yielding a detection level of 20sigma), allowing for the proper study of the source-plane dynamics and structure.

The TDM velocity resolution (~40km/s) is too coarse to provide a proper sampling of the CO(2-1) line FWHM (380km/s to 480km/s, depending on the knot), a line with which one wants to assess the source dynamics. As a result, the coarsest of the FDM set-ups is chosen with a 16 spectral-averaging, reducing the data rate and providing a line-sampling factor of 37-47, enough to address the proposed goal.
Two other windows cover the CI 3P1-3P0 and CS(10-9) which have already been detected in the Cycle0 data-set. The CS(10-9) was only detected in brightest of the knots, hence these new observations are expected to allow for spatially resolved CO- or CI-to-CS line-ratios.
The remaining spectral window probes the continuum.

The requested angular resolution was chosen so that beam matched observations in CO J:2-1, CO J:4-3, and CO J:6-5 could be pursued, provided the ALMA Cycle3 configurations. Also, the requested resolution is similar to that achieved by HST and Keck-AO observations (Messias et al. 2014).
The requested resolution is also necessary to avoid blending with a possible foreground continuum detection.
The specified largest angular scale (LAS) is likely and upper limit, since the emission is limited to the Einstein ring (1.4arcsec in diameter, smaller than the recoverable LAS) and the tidal feature.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(6-5) emission in the lensed (background) galaxy: constrain CO SLED and lens model
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
All lines targeted are from the lensed (background) galaxy:
Resolve the CO(6-5) emission from the Einstein ring at 0.1arcsec resolution, the same requested for CO(2-1) and CO(4-3) line ratio analysis.
Targetting the CO(6-5) transition will also allow to constrain the intermediate-J part of the CO SLED, before attempting even higher J transitions.
Test the detection of HCO+(8-7).
Continuum: attempt the detection of continuum emission from the foreground galaxy to improve foreground/background spectral energy distribution modelling.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The target source has been observed by ALMA in Cycle-0. Its morphology consists of three knots, with the faintest appearing in the Nort-West. Its measured fluxes are the reference to estimate the requested sensitivity. We consider the knots to be point-like down to a resolution of 0.1arcsec as evidenced by HST and Keck observations, thus we do not correct for the finer resolution requested in this proposal. We consider AOT default weather conditions.
The CO(6-5) transition has not been observed by any observatory so far toward this source. Hence, we assume typical CO(4-3) to CO(1-0) luminosity ratios observed for SMGs (0.46, Table 2 in Carilli & Walter 2013), and, conservatively, the lowest CO(6-5) to CO(1-0) intensity ratio observed in SMGs so far (6, Figure 4 in Carilli & Walter 2013). This yields a CO(6-5) to CO(4-3) intensity ratio of 0.83. As a result, comparing with the requested sensitivity in the CO(4-3) science goal, we request a sensitivity of 0.64mJy at a spectral resolution of 27km/s.

The TDM velocity resolution (~27km/s) is expected to sample well enought the CO(6-5) line profile, and since the line flux is nevertheless unknown, this was the chosen set-up.
One spectral window was tunned to the HCO+(8-7) just for the purpose of detection test.
The remainder spectral windows probe the continuum.

The requested angular resolution was chosen so that beam matched observations in CO J:2-1, CO J:4-3, and CO J:6-5 could be pursued, provided the ALMA Cycle3 configurations. Also, the requested resolution is similar to that achieved by HST and Keck-AO observations (Messias et al. 2014).
The requested resolution is also necessary to avoid blending with a possible foreground continuum detection.
The specified largest angular scale (LAS) is likely and upper limit, since the emission is limited to the Einstein ring (1.4arcsec in diameter, smaller than the recoverable LAS) and the tidal feature.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The chance alignment of a massive galaxy with a background source, producing a flux and spatial magnification of the latter, enables a study of galaxy properties well beyond the typical observatory's capabilities. This proposal focuses on one gravitational lens system selected in the Herschel-ATLAS as a bright (S_500um = 227mJy) 160um-``peaker'' source. The target was (partially) observed in Cycle-0 and with what the team has learned so far with the delivered and ancillary data, we propose: (1) spatially-matched resolved observations of the CO J:2-1, J:4-3, and J:6-5 transitions to constrain the spatially resolved CO excitation and confirm the detection of a tidal tail also observed at 1100nm; (2) observation of the 13CO and C18O isotopes to calibrate molecular gas mass estimates (this is one of the three science goals, among five, not observed in Cycle-0); (3) foreground galaxy dynamics via observation of the CO J:2-1 transition to improve the lens model.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00476.S (ALMA Cycle 0; PI G. Orellana) 2013.1.01304.S (ALMA Cycle 2; PI H. Messias; not chosen for observation)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
